title: Roy Jack
text:
Sir Roy Emile Jack (12 January 1914 – 24 December 1977) was a New Zealand politician of the <a href="New%20Zealand%20National%20Party">National Party</a>. He was a <a href="Cabinet%20of%20New%20Zealand">cabinet</a> minister and <a href="Speaker%20of%20the%20New%20Zealand%20House%20of%20Representatives">Speaker of the House of Representatives</a>.
Biography.
Early life and career.
Jack was born in <a href="New%20Plymouth">New Plymouth</a> in 1914. He was educated at <a href="Wanganui%20Collegiate%20School">Wanganui Collegiate School</a> and graduated from the <a href="Victoria%20University%20of%20Wellington">Victoria University</a> with an LLB. Jack was a Judge's Associate from 1935-1938, before enlisting with the <a href="Royal%20New%20Zealand%20Air%20Force">Royal New Zealand Air Force</a> during World War Two. He was first elected onto Wanganui City Council in 1946 and was deputy mayor in the following year. He served on the city council until 1955.
Member of Parliament.
He represented the electorate of <a href="Patea%20%28New%20Zealand%20electorate%29">Patea</a> from to 1963, then from to 1972, then <a href="Rangit%C4%ABkei%20%28New%20Zealand%20electorate%29">Rangitikei</a> from to 1977 when he died.
The electorate became because of post-census boundary changes before the , and though a sitting MP he was challenged by <a href="Ruth%20Richardson">Ruth Richardson</a> (who he had advised about a career in politics). <a href="George%20Chapman%20%28party%20president%29">George Chapman</a> who chaired the selection said that "t"he tensions were tremendous, but Roy was finally confirmed as the candidate."" He had an election-night majority of 2067 in 1972, down from <a href="Norman%20Shelton">Shelton</a>'s 1969 majority of 4214.
In the 1972 Marshall Ministry of the last year of the <a href="Second%20National%20Government%20of%20New%20Zealand">Second National Government</a>, he was <a href="Attorney-General%20%28New%20Zealand%29">Attorney-General</a> and <a href="Minister%20of%20Justice%20%28New%20Zealand%29">Minister of Justice</a>. He was <a href="Chairman%20of%20Committees%20%28New%20Zealand%20House%20of%20Representatives%29">Chairman of Committees</a> between 1961 and 1966. He was Speaker of the House of Representatives from 1967 to 1972 and 1976 to 1977.
Death.
He died in 1977 on <a href="Christmas%20Eve">Christmas Eve</a> in his office at parliament.
Honours.
In the <a href="1970%20Birthday%20Honours%20%28New%20Zealand%29">1970 Queen's Birthday Honours</a>, Jack was appointed a <a href="Knight%20Bachelor">Knight Bachelor</a>, for outstanding services as Speaker of the House of Representatives.
